oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury: Role of Oxygen Radicals
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Korthuis, Ronald J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: oxygen radicals
ischemic tissues
hypoxanthine
free radicals
granulocyte adhesion
tissue injury
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oxygen radicals appear to be produced upon reperfusion of ischemic tissues according to the following mechanism: During an ischemic period, xanthine dehydrogenase is converted to xanthine oxidase. Concomitantly, ATP is catabolized to hypoxanthine, which accumulates in the tissues. Upon reperfusion, molecular oxygen is reintroduced and reacts with hypoxanthine and xanthine oxidase to produce a burst of superoxide anion radicals and hydrogen peroxide with subsequent formation of hydroxyl radicals. These highly reactive and cytotoxic free radicals then cause tissue injury through lipid peroxidation of cell membranes, degradation of hyaluronic acid and possibly by promoting granulocyte adhesion and subsequent activation. The purpose of this review is to provide a description of the evidence in support of this hypothesis.
